message.content:
Statement to verify: In 2001, the tobacco advertising prohibition act 1992 banned almost all forms of tobacco advertising in Australia, including the sponsorship of sporting or other cultural events by cigarette brands. Domestic sponsorships were allowed to run their course until 1998 when they naturally expired. The act also allowed the federal minister for health and ageing to grant exemptions for events of international significance that would not be held in Australia without tobacco advertising. This led to only two events being eligible by 2006 - the Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix and the Australian Formula One Grand Prix. However, in 2007, the Australian Grand Prix featured no tobacco advertising of any sort as the minister's right to grant exemptions was removed in 2006.

1. Which specific provisions of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 banned tobacco advertising in Australia and allowed exemptions for certain events?
2. Can you provide evidence or documentation confirming the inclusion of the Australian Motorcycle Grand Prix and the Australian Formula One Grand Prix as the only eligible events under the exemptions by 2006?
3. Who was the federal minister for health and ageing in 2006 when the right to grant exemptions for tobacco advertising was removed?
4. Is there official documentation or reports verifying that the Australian Grand Prix in 2007 featured no tobacco advertising due to the removal of the minister's right to grant exemptions in 2006?
